Title_Description: externalreference issue when loading fbx to test 4875 i wanted to try the [instancedmodel sample]( but i ran into some issues importing a .fbx model. - first there was a problem in the contentwriter about writing a non-.xnb file. this was caused by [effectmaterialcontent.effect]( being serialized since its an external reference to a non-xnb file. this was an easy fix i solved it by adding [contentserializerignore] above it. - second there was an error thrown [here]( because the filename of the reference did not begin with the root directory which was caused by [normalizeos]( in externalreference since it changed directory separators in the externalreference so the strings didnt match up. also an easy fix  i changed that so it does a regular normalize rather than normalizeos (do the separators really matter as long as theyre consistent? normalizeos is now not used anymore).- after that it built fine  however when loading the model it cant find the content reader for externalreference<compiledeffectcontent. this is the hard one p after digging through the code a bit i think it should resolve to a regular externalreferencereader so it can load the file thats referenced (the reader for the effect itself is loaded so that would work) but i got a bit confused when i saw the content readers include        it seems weird to have a reader for a specific generic type like that i thought a generic reader should read its content and delegate to the reader that can handle it. in this case i would expect a namedvaluedictionaryreader an externalreferencereader and a texturecontentreader to handle a type like this each delegating internally to the next. so my question is if i should make the writer when asked for the runtime reader write out the full name of the type (e.g. externalreferencereader1[[sometype]]) or make [contenttypereadermanager.gettypereader]( a bit smarter to use a reader for the outer type when it encounters generics. i really wouldnt go for the first option but i dont know if the second one is applicable in general (for all generic types). i think we could make it work though and it would be   a lot   neater.

need1. a new plain windows desktop monogame project2. a resource file named pixel.xnb which is a 2d-texture that simply contains a single black pixel.what it does is to draw a horizontal black line with a height of 5 pixels on a white background and move it vertical in steps of 5 pixels every frame. works perfectly with 3d vision deactivated but if 3d vision kicks in the following happens [timingglitch](it turned out that it was impossible to get a regular screenshot from the glitch so i needed to take a photograph of my screen. so please ignore the unsharp grey stripes - they are a side-effect of taking a photograph of the screen and not really there. what is the real glitch are the 3 thin horizontal lines there only should be one which is the lowest of them.if you could see the movement the glitch lines appear to be flickering (i think about 20 times/second see my theory below). but taking a video of the glitch is even more impossible (120 hz video camera anyone? d ). then the glitch lines change their position at random points of time.looking through my 3d glasses it appeared that the glitch lines are only in the half-picture intended for the right eye the left eye looks normal. theory after some research about the internal workings of directx graphics and how monogame uses it i came up with the following theory how this happens1. monogame creates a swapchain in the video memory which consists of a screen buffer and 2 back buffers2. since 3d vision needs 2 half-pictures it creates secondary buffers for the right eye. it doesnt tell the application anything about that (wouldnt be possible with older 3d games that are automatically converted into stereo 3d)3. when a frame should be drawn monogame sends draw instructions to the graphics card and waits until they are executed then presents the next buffer in the swapchain.4. monogame (or sharpdx?) uses some unusual way to determine when the draw operations are finished. at least i assume it must be unusual since i never noticed the same problem in other 3d games. the call returns when the first buffer has been drawn the secondary buffer has not yet been drawn.5. under normal circumstances the next frame is drawn now. if that happens the preceding draw operations are cancelled. the secondary buffer remains unchanged.6. only at random times (for example when the operating system gives cpu time to another thread or process) the graphics card is given enough time to execute the drawing operations for the seondary buffer. then the secondary buffer is changed.7. the screen is presented with the contents of the primary and secondary buffers. since the secondary buffer contains an old version of the drawing from some random point of time in the past a flickering ghost will appear. since there are 3 secondary buffers it flickers at a rate of      120 hz / 2 (half pictures/second) / 3 (buffers/half-picture) = 20 hz      there are up to 3 ghosts because we have 3 secondary buffers. workaroundto test my theory i just gave the graphics card more time to finish by adding a thread.sleep() to the draw cycle. to test remove the slashes from the line thread.sleep( (int)gametime.elapsedgametime.totalmilliseconds/8); in my code sample. i found the appropriate amount of time with trial and error it may be system dependent.on my system this removes all the graphic glitches. suggestions for solutionthe second best solution would be to deactivate 3d vision in monogame completely. there is an api (nvapi.dll) that allows game developers to control 3d vision so monogame would need to check wether it is present and make the appropriate calls.the best solution would be of course to fix the source of the problem since this would allow to write 3d-vision Title_Description: content pipeline support for arbitrary text config files (including json yaml etc.) this is a feature request / design review for functionality that im happy to implement   contribute as long as the monogame devs approve of the concept. comments / suggestions welcome    proposal  right now the monogame content pipeline has the ability to import xml files via xmlimporter but many folks would rather keep metadata   config files in a different format such as json windows ini / .cfg files yaml etc.  rather than implementing separate processors for every possible plain-text file format i propose adding a generic textimporter to the content pipeline which simply reads the associated file and presents it to the user as a c string. the user can then parse it with their favorite json / yaml (etc) parser; for example   this  works  but im not proud of it. it feels slightly cursed.   questions    how do we handle the encoding of the input text files? my preference would be to only support utf-8 files or perhaps to make two separate importers utf8importer and utf16importer for the two most-common unicode formats.   expected limitations    we will not handle legacy non-unicode file encodings such as windows code pages shift-jis and so on.    the text file will be loaded into a single string in memory. a user who wants to load a file thats too big to fit in memory should probably implement their own streaming loading system instead of trying to use the proposed textimporter.
